page.title: 16Bird Watching in Horton
page.content:
{Habitats}Farmland, moorland, riverside and wooded becksides mean that a great many varieties of birds can be seen.
{Varieties}Apart from the more common birds,{grey }and{pied wagtails }often visit the school playground. This year,{swallows }nested in the school boiler house as well as in local barns. {House martins} nest in Chapel Lane. A {goldfinch}was seen near Horton Bridge.
Along the River Ribble it is possible to see {heron, sand martins, }and if lucky a {kingfisher} or a {dipper. { In the fields {lapwings} and {curlews} are common. In the few patches of woodland one might see a{nuthatch} or a {treecreeper.} Most evenings {owls} can be heard, if not seen.
